article.title: Long-term unemployment is becoming 'a status quo' in today's job market

summary: Long-term unemployment in the U.S. is rising, with one in four unemployed individuals jobless for over six months—a trend persisting despite economic recovery. This stagnation reflects broader labor market challenges including fewer job openings, increased competition, and employers’ cautious hiring amid economic and geopolitical uncertainties.

rewrite.title: Long-Term Unemployment Solidifies in U.S. Job Market
rewrite.body:
Long-term unemployment is becoming entrenched in the U.S. labor market, with 1.8 million Americans—one in four unemployed—searching for work for six months or more as of early 2026. This marks a sustained rise over three years, contrasting with previous recoveries after recessions like the 2008 financial crisis or the pandemic, when long-term unemployment typically declined. Many of these workers have exhausted unemployment benefits, which on average replace less than 40% of prior earnings, intensifying financial strain.

Job seekers face fierce competition; data from mid-2025 shows that each job opening attracted an average of 242 applicants, triple the volume seen in 2017. This surge in applications, combined with cautious employer hiring due to economic headwinds—such as persistent inflation, high interest rates, new tariff policies, and shifting priorities toward AI investments—has led to stagnation. Workers are less likely to switch jobs voluntarily, and many are accepting lateral moves or pay cuts, with fewer landing positions they consider their 'dream jobs.'

The prolonged unemployment period also carries long-term consequences beyond finances, including declines in mental and physical health and reduced future earnings, often 5% to 15% lower than peers who remained employed. Job seekers report frustration with opaque hiring processes and frequent lack of feedback, further complicating their efforts. This environment underscores the need for both policy and employer responses to address the persistent challenges facing long-term unemployed Americans.
